article.headline: Iowa 66, Minnesota 62
article.story: IOWA CITY, Iowa (AP) -- Brody Boyd and Glen Worley made sure the last regular-season home game of their careers wasn't spoiled by last minute Minnesota heroics. Boyd made a key steal and three clutch free throws in the final minutes, and Worley's jumper with 4:14 left ended a seven-minute field goal drought that helped lift Iowa to a 66-62 victory Saturday. Their play on both ends of the court helped the Hawkeyes (15-10, 8-6 Big Ten) squelch Minnesota's rally from a 19-point second-half deficit. "It was an emotional game," said Boyd, who led his team with 16 points and was one of four Hawkeye seniors honored during the game. "You can't give away a lead like that, especially at home," he said. "We got up big and we felt too comfortable. Then we played passive and you just can't do that." The Golden Gophers, playing without Big Ten leading scorer Kris Humphries, were down 57-38 with 11:22 remaining and hadn't made a field goal for more than seven minutes. But Adam Boone's driving layup, followed by a free throw, ended the drought and fueled a 16-1 run. Brent Lawson capped the surge when he scored in traffic inside with 4::44 to go close the gap 58-54. Worley got Iowa back on track on the next possession when he drove an open lane to the basket. But Minnesota answered when Ben Johnson nailed a pull-up jumper to cut Iowa's lead back to four. Minnesota coach Dan Monson credited the rally to his team's aggressive mentality and defense -- traits the Gophers have lacked all too often this year. "We've just got to learn how to dictate the game for longer periods of time," Monson said. "I felt we ended the game in the last seven minutes or so with us being the aggressors, especially at the defensive end." But the Gophers would get no closer, thanks to heady plays down the stretch from Iowa's veterans. Worley coaxed Boone into a charging foul at the 1:15 mark. In the final minute, Boyd pickpocketed Stan Gaines in the paint and hit three free throws in three separate trips to the line to preserve Iowa's lead and its thin hopes for an NCAA Tournament bid. "We're still in the mix," said Iowa coach Steve Alford, whose team closes out the season on the road next week against Northwestern and Purdue. "I'm really proud of the kids because we knew this would be a hard fought game. I thought the guys did a good job the last few minutes of getting stops and getting the ball to the people who need to be at the free throw line late in the game," he said. With Humphries out with a sore ankle, Michael Bauer picked up some of the slack and led Minnesota with 16 points, including four 3-pointers. Boone added 14 points, but the Gophers shot just 38.6 percent as a team, including 33.3 percent from 3-point range. Iowa got 14 points from Jeff Horner and Greg Brunner scored 13 points and grabbed 12 rebounds. Iowa shot 55 percent in the first half but cooled in the second, hitting just 32 percent from the field after halftime. "It wasn't' a pretty win, but we'll take it," said Boyd, who also had four assists and four steals. "A win's a win in this league, no matter if it's number one or 19. We'll build from it."
